dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, uh, you know, we've got some pretty wild political drama unfolding in the UK right now. Starmer, the PM, is really, like, laying down the law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. He's, uh, warning his own Labour MPs, the rebels, that they're basically undermining Brexit negotiations. Like, "vote against delaying it, or else."

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Or else" being the operative phrase there, right? He's really doubling down on that December 31st exit, come what may.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or else being the operative phrase there, right? He's really doubling down on that December thirty first exit, come what may.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...he doubled down on his oft-repeated promise to leave the trading bloc by October 31 come what may.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he's saying the EU can see Britain *wants* a deal, and these rebel MPs are just, like, making it look weak. Making negotiations "absolutely possible" is what he said, which is a bit of a weird way to put it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he's saying the E U can see Britain wants a deal, and these rebel MPs are just, like, making it look weak. Making negotiations absolutely possible is what he said, which is a bit of a weird way to put it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...accusing them of making further negotiations absolutely impossible.

dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which, uh, I guess means impossible? Like, he's kinda hinting that their actions are making a deal harder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, I guess means impossible? Like, he's kinda hinting that their actions are making a deal harder.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And then he throws in, "I want an election, you all want an election!" after this emergency cabinet meeting. Total power move.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And then he throws in, I want an election, you all want an election! after this emergency cabinet meeting. Total power move.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson speaking outside 10 Downing Street said: I don't want an election, you don't want an election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It's like, he's daring everyone. And you know, there are these rumors he's gonna *expel* or block Labour MPs from standing if they support these opposition attempts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It's like, he's daring everyone. And you know, there are these rumors he's gonna expel or block Labour MPs from standing if they support these opposition attempts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It follows reports that Johnson is gearing up to expel or block opposition Tory MPs from standing for election in the next election...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Can you imagine? His own party! And all this, uh, after he just prorogued Parliament last week. So now the opposition has, like, just a week to try and draft a bill to block a no-deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Can you imagine? His own party! And all this, uh, after he just prorogued Parliament last week. So now the opposition has, like, just a week to try and draft a bill to block a no-deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnsons move to suspendor prorogueParliament last week... means that oppositions MPs have just a week to draft a bill and secure the votes needed to make it law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And their plan, if he doesn't strike a deal by October 29th, is apparently for a six-month delay. That's what they're pushing for.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And their plan, if he doesn't strike a deal by October twenty ninth, is apparently for a six-month delay. That's what they're pushing for.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Opposition MPs are reportedly proposing a three-month Brexit delay if Johnson does not strike a deal at the European Council, a summit of EU leaders, on October 19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a six-month delay, which, you know, given the timeline, means they have to get a bill passed *fast*. Which is, frankly, insane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a six-month delay, which, you know, given the timeline, means they have to get a bill passed fast. Which is, frankly, insane.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the UK is still set to leave on December 31st, deal or no deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the U K is still set to leave on December thirty first, deal or no deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As it stands, the U.K. is due to leave the European Union on October 31 with or without a deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep. And, uh, you could hear the protests outside Downing Street too, chanting "go, go, go." Thousands out over the weekend against that prorogation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep. And, uh, you could hear the protests outside Downing Street too, chanting go, go, go. Thousands out over the weekend against that prorogation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a mess. And here's a wild fact, if an election *does* happen this year, it would be the fourth in four years in the UK.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a mess. And here's a wild fact, if an election does happen this year, it would be the fourth in four years in the U K.

dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] The fourth! Unbelievable. Just, uh, you know, never a dull moment in British politics, I guess.
